Many films are called "classic." Very few advance and redefine the language of cinema. L'Avventura is such a film. What it showed was that films do not have to be structured around major events, that very little drama can happen and a film can still be fascinating to its audience. It also showed -- and this was harder for audiences to grasp (and still is) -- that events in films do not have to be, in an obvious way, meaningful. L'Avventura presents its characters behaving according to motivations unclear to themselves as much as to the audience; they are sensitive to mood, to landscape, to things that happen, but they also behave in routine and conformist ways. None of them, except Claudia (who had, in her words, "a sensible childhood, without any money"), seems to have much consciousness of the lack of direction that afflicts them. They are, to use a word very fashionable at the time the film came out, alienated. But to say, as many critics did, that the film is "about" alienation is to miss the point. More than any other film L'Avventura seems to define the spirit of a time in cinema when anything seemed possible and there was no territory into which it could not venture. (The more I think about it, post-war Italian cinema may be my favorite "genre." It didn't succumb to any filmic conventions, and approached weighty subject matter with grace and elegance.) Above all what it seeks to capture is the world of fleeting emotion, feelings which are unstable and crystallize only momentarily in the camera's gaze. After L'Avventura, Antonioni did not look back. He made three further films with Monica Vitti --The Night (1961), Eclipse (1962), and Red Desert (1964) -- each time pushing further back the frontiers of what cinema could explore. It's hard to say which of these films is the best, but L'Avventura is the one that started Antonioni on his quest, and remains the one that most clearly represents the unique nature of his art.

Michelangelo Antonioni does not fallow the modern conventions of storytelling in the remarkable, "L'Avventura". Antonioni seems to find this bourgeois approach to film unsuited for the questions and feelings which he is attempting to evoke. The would be plot element of the missing person is used only to spark the internal struggles of the characters as they cope with the boredom of every day life. yes it bored me. yes it took me a week or so watch it. but is that the film's fault or my own laziness? my own inability to grant the attention a film this complex, challenging, and brilliant deserves? what threw me off was the structure. the tone and content of the first 30 minutes of the film are merely the back-story/prologue. the thing that's confusing is that the prologue is so visceral and entertaining, and the actual story starts off so slowly, that the shift feels very jarring. 

the film surprised me in the risks it took with Monica Vitti's character, Claudia. this is really her story. and the film channels all kinds of statements and provocations into the dynamics between men and women through Claudia's story. the film examines the dysfunctional dance between men and women- in particular, how women are trapped by the male gaze, how it permeates their psychology. and how easily men become disappointment with women, for contradicting the male idealization of women while struggling- inauthentic, and unsuccessful to be the ideal. when sandro  pushes the bottle of ink onto the sketch of the beautiful dome drawn by the young man, the symbolism is clear: men foolishly obsess over women, try to reconstruct them in their heads, idealizing them...but the ideal, the reconstructed image of woman is phony and fake, and not worth 'drawing' which is a vocation of the young and the foolish (such as the horny painter in the middle section). 

Men are presented as callous, horny, cheating, and somehow always at a distance from that which they most desire. The repeated shots of scores of men in the village publicly gazing at a single woman, capture the mystique that women have to men-- but also the very real, threatening power men have over women, and rape is literally a subject of the film twice. the film shows empathy towards its female characters, and in Claudia, the main character, Vitti and Antonioni create a character who functions as both a symbol of idealized femininity as well as a believable, often quirky woman struggling to understand for herself how to deal with men.
